title: 104_s1857
content: The "Bipartisan Campaign Practices Commission Act of 1996" establishes the Bipartisan Commission on Campaign Practices with specific duties. The Bipartisan Commission on Campaign Practices established by the "Bipartisan Campaign Practices Commission Act of 1996" is tasked with studying laws and regulations affecting Federal campaign practices. It will consider the amount of money spent on campaigns, the impact of current laws on qualified candidates, the promotion of trust in the political process, and ensuring media access for the electorate. The Bipartisan Commission on Campaign Practices, established by the "Bipartisan Campaign Practices Commission Act of 1996," will study laws and regulations affecting Federal campaign practices. This includes examining the amount of money spent on campaigns, the impact of current laws on qualified candidates, promoting trust in the political process, ensuring media access for the electorate, and other relevant matters as deemed appropriate by the Commission. SEC. 4. MEMBERSHIP. The Commission consists of 9 private sector members appointed by various leaders. A chairperson is selected by majority vote within 7 days of all appointments. The Commission consists of 9 private sector members appointed by various leaders. A chairperson is selected by majority vote within 7 days of all appointments. If the chairperson position remains vacant after 30 days, all current members will be discharged. Vacancies will be filled in the same manner as the original appointment. Each member is entitled to compensation based on the Executive Schedule. A quorum of six members is required for any decision of the Commission. The Commission consists of 9 private sector members appointed by various leaders, with a chairperson selected by majority vote within 7 days. If the chairperson position remains vacant after 30 days, all current members will be discharged. Each member is entitled to compensation based on the Executive Schedule. Six members of the Commission constitute a quorum, and any decision requires the affirmative vote of 6 members. The Commission meets at the call of the chairperson or at the request of 6 members. The chairperson of the Commission can appoint necessary staff without following standard appointment procedures. They can also procure temporary services as authorized by law. Additionally, fast track procedures for recommendations are in place. The Commission must submit a report to Congress within 30 days of the 105th Congress convening, detailing the study conducted. Recommendations for changes in laws governing Federal campaigns may be included, with bills prepared for implementation if 7 or more members agree on a recommendation. The implementing bills will be submitted for consideration by Congress. The implementing bill must be submitted with a report to Congress within 30 days. It will receive expedited consideration similar to trade agreements under the Trade Act of 1974. The Commission will cease to exist 30 days after submitting the report. $750,000 is authorized for carrying out this Act.
